G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: This action arises from Defendant’s breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment implied in Plaintiff’s residential tenancy at the Premises, in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and Massachusetts common law.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, § 3, because this is a civil action involving residential housing and tenancies located within the territorial jurisdiction of the Housing Court Department, Boston Division.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, because the Premises are located in Roxbury, Massachusetts, within the Court’s jurisdiction, and the cause of action arose there.

State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000.raw_text: State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.
State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000.proposition: Defendant’s breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment is further evidenced by the city inspection findings of water intrusion and other code issues, showing noncompliance with the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.500 (structural elements to be kept in good repair and watertight), 410.550 (dampness and water penetration), and 410.602 (maintenance of dwellings in compliance with the Code).

105 C.M.R. 410.500, 410.550, 410.602.proposition: The existence of water entering a basement apartment through a wall during rainfall is a condition that can violate the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to provisions requiring that dwelling units be maintained in a watertight condition and free from chronic dampness. See 105 C.M.R. 410.500, 410.550, 410.602.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 18.proposition: The timing of Defendant’s decision and her statements, occurring shortly after Plaintiff contacted city authorities about the water condition, strongly suggest that Defendant’s decision not to renew is in fact retaliatory and linked to Plaintiff’s protected complaints and the inspection. See G.L. c. 186, § 18.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: Although this Complaint focuses on the breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Plaintiff notes that the same facts may also implicate related statutory protections, including but not limited to G.L. c. 239, § 8A (defenses and counterclaims in summary process), G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L (State Sanitary Code enforcement), and G.L. c. 186, § 18 (retaliation), and the Court may consider those statutes in interpreting the scope and seriousness of the landlord’s obligations and the remedies available.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2013127L.proposition: Although this Complaint focuses on the breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Plaintiff notes that the same facts may also implicate related statutory protections, including but not limited to G.L. c. 239, § 8A (defenses and counterclaims in summary process), G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L (State Sanitary Code enforcement), and G.L. c. 186, § 18 (retaliation), and the Court may consider those statutes in interpreting the scope and seriousness of the landlord’s obligations and the remedies available.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award pre-judgment and post-judgment interest as allowed by G.L. c. 231, § 6B and other applicable law; and

Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease or tenancy in Massachusetts. See G.L. c. 186, § 14; Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33 (1929).
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses an implied covenant or obligation that the lessor refrain from acts that substantially impair the character and value of the leased premises, and recognizes that wrongful interference can also constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. However, it does not state that a covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease or tenancy in Massachusetts, nor does it rely on G.L. c. 186, § 14 or on the residential nature of the tenancy. The case concerns a dental office lease and focuses on landlord interference and related tort/nuisance principles, so it does not affirm the broad residential-lease proposition claimed.
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.relevant_excerpt: “The lease carried with it an implication that the lessors would refrain from acts voluntarily undertaken which substantially ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Brande v. Grace, supra, page 212. … The same act may be a breach of the covenant for quiet enjoyment and also a wrong causing injury to the tenant for which injunctive relief might be sought or an action of tort would lie.”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Defendant, as landlord and owner, is responsible for complying with the State Sanitary Code and maintaining the Premises in a habitable condition. See Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: The concurring/dissenting opinion explicitly states that the State Sanitary Code imposes on the owner the duty to comply with minimum standards of fitness for human habitation and that this obligation runs for the benefit of tenants. It further explains that the Code ‘expressly places the burden on the owner to comply’ with those standards and endorses a rule that, by renting, the landlord impliedly agrees to provide and maintain premises meeting those legal requirements. This directly supports the proposition that a landlord/owner is responsible for complying with the State Sanitary Code and maintaining premises in a habitable condition.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “Since 1960 dwelling units have been subject to the State Sanitary Code… The Code… fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation… It expressly provides that ‘[n]o person shall … let to another for occupancy any dwelling… which does not comply’ with its provisions… It expressly places the burden on the owner to comply with the prescribed minimum physical standards for rented dwelling units.… I would… hold… that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards.”}

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977) (landlord’s acts or omissions that substantially interfere with tenant’s use amount to breach of quiet enjoyment, even without intent);
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The court expressly rejects any requirement of intent and holds that a landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment, giving rise to constructive eviction, where substantial interference with the tenant’s use is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted, and where the landlord had the right and ability to control the condition. The opinion emphasizes that “the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling,” which directly supports the proposition that such acts or omissions amount to a breach even without intent.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979) (landlord’s failure to correct conditions violating State Sanitary Code supports liability);
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The case squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to maintain premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code—here, failure to provide adequate heat and hot water—constitutes a material breach of the implied warranty of habitability and supports rent abatement, regardless of fault or reasonable repair efforts. The court repeatedly ties habitability to compliance with the State Sanitary Code and treats noncompliance as rendering the unit uninhabitable, triggering the landlord’s liability for rent abatement once the landlord has notice. Thus it supports the proposition that failure to correct Sanitary Code violations supports landlord liability.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he essential objective of the leasing transaction is to provide a dwelling suitable for habitation.’ … A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for. … The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water. … The landlord can have no reasonable grounds to believe that noncompliance will be acceptable.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994) (recognizing breadth of quiet enjoyment protections in residential settings);
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court squarely applies and extends the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment (G.L. c. 186, § 14) in a residential, multi-unit setting to cover serious interference caused by third‑party criminal/drug activity in common areas, based on the landlord’s omissions. It recognizes that loss of use of residential common areas (sidewalks, streets, recreation areas) because of such activity can constitute a serious interference with tenants’ quiet enjoyment and allows injunctive and damages relief, thereby affirming a broad scope of quiet enjoyment protections in residential housing.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold… In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises… [I]f the defendant has failed to take any measures… then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982) (summary eviction and serious conditions may constitute breach of quiet enjoyment);
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, regardless of financial inability. However, the case does not involve or discuss a summary process/summary eviction as part of the quiet enjoyment violation; the landlord’s summary process claim was dismissed on a technical notice issue and not tied to the § 14 breach. Thus, it supports the proposition that serious conditions (lack of heat) may constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment, but not that summary eviction does so in this case.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season…seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’…and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’ … On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to (a) a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14….”

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987) (substantial interference with use of premises, including code violations, established breach of quiet enjoyment).
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion mentions various State Sanitary Code violations but explicitly states that most had only minimal impact on use and enjoyment, and it treats those conditions primarily in the context of warranty of habitability and rent abatement, not breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court never analyzes or finds a violation of G.L. c. 186, §14, nor does it hold that substantial interference with use of premises or code violations constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment. Thus, the case does not establish the specific quiet-enjoyment principle claimed in the proposition.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: "Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property. The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs. ... The judge properly could have disregarded the minor code violations. McKenna, 5 Mass. App. Ct. at 308. There is record support for the amount awarded."
